module.p: rach go is an irregular simple verb. It generally denotes a (distal) event of motion along a trajectory, usually not towards the speaker or other deictic centre (cf. the equivalent proximal verb thig come).

section.p:
The principal parts of rach are –
thèid – future independent will go
chaidh – past independent went
rachadh – conditional independent would go
dol – verbal noun going

ol.li: The conditional stem varies according to dialect – deigh–, geobh-, rach-, reigh-, reagh-, deidh-.
The future dependent forms in tèid- are pronounced as if they were spelled dèid-.
There is a dialectal alternative to past dependent deach ie. deachaidh.

section.p:
The subject of rach is usually a noun or pronoun denoting one or more human beings moving somewhere under their own volition –
Chaidh Raonaid dhan bhaile. Rachel went into town.
Cha tèid na balaich dhachaigh. The boys won’t go home.
An deigheadh iad a-mach gu tric? Would they go out a lot?

Some examples –
proper nouns –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh Iain a-mach. Cha deach Uilleam a-mach. | Cha tèid Màiri air lathaichean saora ged a bhios an t-airgead aice. | Thèid Anna a Ghlaschu a h-uile Dimàirt. | Is ann an-dè a chaidh Iain a Ghlaschu. | Chaidh Anna a dh’fhuireach còmhla ri Peigi. | Chaidh Iain gan iarraidh. | Chaidh Calum ga coimhead. | An abradh tu gun rachadh Iain dhan an dealbh-chluich?
John went out. William did not go out. | Mary will not go on holiday even though she will have the money. | Ann goes to Glasgow every Tuesday. | It is yesterday that John went to Glasgow. | Ann went to stay with Peggy. | John went to get them. | Calum went to watch her. | Would you say that John would go to the drama? td. 38–9, 105, 120, 144, 153, 156, 157 [199], 169 [199]
common nouns –
pedagogical examples –
An tèid do bhràthair dhan a’ chèilidh? | an tidsear a chaidh a mhac a Pheairt
Will your brother go to the cèilidh? | the teacher whose son went to Perth td. 119 [197–8], 121
pronouns –
first person –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh mi suas. | Chaidh mi a Pheairt a chionn is gun robh mo charaid a’ fuireach ann. | Thèid sinn a Ghlaschu. Dè nì sinn ma thèid sinn air chall? | am baile tron an deach sinn | Càite an tèid mi airson nan tiocaidean?
I went up(stairs). | I went to Perth because my friend was living there. | We will go to Glasgow. What will we do if we get lost? | the town through which we went | Where can I go for the tickets? td. 39, 105, 118, 123, 134
Thèid mi air ais don talla.
I’ll go back to the hall. td. 476

pedagogical examples –

Did you go across the river or past Càrn Sheumais? td. 99
An tèid thu còmhla rium? | An rachadh tu air ais a-rithist?
Will you go with me? | Would you go back again? td. 476, 477
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” [...] td. 5
third person –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh iad a cheannach leabhraichean.
They went to buy books. td. 154
Nach tèid iad don chèilidh? | Chaidh iad don àrd-sgoil anns an ath bhaile. An deach(aidh) iad don eaglais? Nach deach(aidh) iad dhachaigh? Nach rachadh iad air bòrd? Chaidh i a dhannsa còmhla ris. Chaidh e a dhùnadh an dorais. Chaidh i a dh’fhosgladh na h-uinneig. | Chaidh e air ais.
Won’t they go to the ceilidh? | They went to the high-school in the next town. Did they go to (the) church? Did they not go home? Wouldn’t they go aboard? She went to dance with him. He went to shut the door. She went to open the window. | He went back. td. 476, 477, 478
older pedagogical examples –
[...] Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. [...]
[...] John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. [...] td. 6
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. Is toigh leis a’ chloinn biadh a ghabhail a muigh ri latha brèagha. Thèid iad dhachaidh feasgar an uair a tha a’ ghrian a’ dol fodha.
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. The children like eating al fresco on a nice day. They will go home in the evening when the sun is going down. td. 6–7

singular –
pedagogical examples –
Rachainn ann nan tigeadh tusa còmhla rium. | Rachainn a Ghlaschu nan tigeadh Anna còmhla rium.
I would go there if you came along with me. | I would go to Glasgow if Ann came with me. td. 168, 176
Rachainn còmhla riut nam b’urrainn dhomh.
I’d go with you if I could. td. 477

pedagogical examples –
Rachamaid dhan an taigh-thasgaidh a h-uile mìos.
We used to go to the museum every month. td. 169 [199]
relativised subjects –
pedagogical examples –
a’ chaileag a chaidh a-mach | a’ chaileag nach deach a-mach
the girl who went out | the girl who did not go out td. 121, 124

When responding to a question, the subject is normally dropped –
An deach thu a Lunnainn? Did you go to London?
Chaidh. Yes, I did.
Cha deach. No, I didn’t.
Càite an tèid Raonaid? Where will Rachel go?
Thèid don bhaile. She will go into town.

Some examples –
yes/no questions –
pedagogical examples –
An deach sibh tarsainn air an abhainn no seachad air Càrn Sheumais? Chaidh, le chèile, agus timcheall air an t-Sìdhean agus ri taobh na mara air an rathad dhachaigh.
Did you go across the river or past Càrn Sheumais? Yes we did, both of them, and round the Sìdhean and beside the sea on the way home. td. 99
Thèid mi air ais don talla. An tèid thu còmhla rium? Cha tèid. | Nach tèid iad don chèilidh? Thèid. | An deach(aidh) iad don eaglais? Cha deach(aidh). | Nach deach(aidh) iad dhachaigh? Chaidh. | An rachadh tu air ais a-rithist? Cha rachadh. | Nach rachadh iad air bòrd? Rachadh.
I’ll go back to the hall. Will you go with me? No, I won’t. | Won’t they go to the ceilidh? Yes, they will. | Did they go to [the] church? No they didn’t. | Did they not go home? Yes, they did. | Would you go back again? Yes, I would. | Wouldn’t the go aboard? Yes, they would. td. 476, ibid, 477, ibid, ibid, ibid
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” [...] td. 5
open questions –
pedagogical examples –
Càite an tèid mi airson nan tiocaidean? Thèid chun an dorais anns a bheil fear an stèisein na sheasamh.
Where can I go for the tickets? To the door where the station-master is standing. td. 134
rach can be used impersonally, without an explicit or even implicit subject, in a number of constructions.

rach can be used impersonally, with a single non-finite verbal argument, as a modern alternative to using a passive form of a verb –
Dh’fhosgail i an uinneag. She opened the window.
Chaidh an uinneag (a) fhosgladh. The window was opened. (cf. Dh’fhosgladh an uinneag.)
Chaidh a fosgladh. It [fem.] was opened. (cf. Dh’fhosgladh i.)
Marbhaidh i am fear. She will kill the man.
Thèid am fear a mharbhadh. The man will be killed. (cf. Marbhar am fear.)
Thèid a mharbhadh. He will be killed. (cf. Marbhar e.)

Some examples –
intransitive –
pedagogical examples –
Thèid innse dhuinn a-nochd. | Chaidh tòiseachadh air an t-siostam ùr an t-seachdain seo chaidh.
We’ll be told tonight. | The new system was begun last week. td. 477 Maybe not intransitive at all?
other examples from modern usage –
Gu cumanta ’s an arm, nuair a rachadh òrdan a dhiùltadh ’s e cionta trom a bh’ ann ’s rachadh deiligeadh ris a chiontach air reir a chiont, ach ’s e bha so gnothach eile.
Usually in the army, when an order was disobeyed it was a serious transgression and the offender would be dealt with according to his crime, but this was another matter td. 10–11
Anns a’ Mhàrt 1992, chaidh ghabhail ri Moladh Eòrpach air cùram-cloinne.
In March 1992, the European Recommendation on childcare was accepted. td. 11 the lenition on ‘ghabhail’ may well be a hypercorrection here
transitive with inversion –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh an doras a dhùnadh. | Chaidh Iain a bhualadh. | Cha deach an telebhisean a ghoid. | An deach am biadh a ithe? | Thèid an càr a reic.
The door was closed. | John was hit. | The television was not stolen. | Was the food eaten? | The car will be sold. td. 172
Nuair a sheallar air na chaidh a sgrìobhadh ann an Gàidhlig, shaoileadh duine gun deach òigridh na Gàidhealtachd a oideachadh nan cànan fhèin ann an sgoiltean na Stàite bho shean. [...] Ann an 1709 chaidh Comann a stèidheachadh ann an Dùn Èideann, le barrantas rìoghail, airson sgoiltean a chur air bhonn gus leughadh is sgrìobhadh a ionnsachadh do mhuinntir na Gàidhlig an Alba agus gu sònraichte airson am Bìoball agus leabhraichean cràbhach a chur an eòlas nan Gàidheal. [...] Ann an 1946 chaidh Gàidhlig a chur air a’ chlàr-oideachaidh ann am beagan sgoiltean anns na bailtean mòra, Glaschu gu h-àraid, airson a’ chiad uair. [...] Chaidh a’ chiad sgoil Ghàidhlig neo-eisimeileach [...] a stèidheachadh ann an Glaschu anns a’ bhliadhna 2006.
When one considers how much has been written in Gaelic, one would think that the youth of the Gaidhealtachd had been instructed in their own language in the schools from olden times. [...] In 1709 a Society was set up in Edinburgh, under royal charter, to establish schools in order to teach reading and writing to the Gaelic speakers in Scotland and particularly to give Gaels a knowledge of the Bible and books of piety. [...] In 1946 Gaelic was placed on the curriculum of a few city schools, especially in Glasgow, for the first time. [...] The first independent Gaelic school [...] was established in Glasgow in 2006. td. 193–4
Chaidh an ròpa a ghearradh. Thèid an doras fhosgladh aig sia uairean. Thuirt e gun deach an càr aige a ghoid.
The rope was cut. The door will be opened at six o’ clock. He said that his car had been stolen. td. 477
examples from Gairm –
An déidh crìoch a’ Chogaidh chaidh deachdaireachdan co-mhaoineach a stéidheachadh le cul-taic an armailt ruiseanaich ann an dùthchannan na h-Eòrpa an Ear.
After the end of the War communist dictatorships were established with the support of the Russian army in the countries of Eastern Europe. td. 121
other examples from modern usage –
’S e litir a bh’ ann gun ainm ’s gun seòladh, agus an àite làmh-sgrìobhaidh bha facail a chaidh a ghearradh à pàipear-naidheachd.
It was a letter with no name or address, and in place of handwriting there were words that had been cut out of a newspaper. td. 107
transitive with pronoun –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh mo bhualadh. Chaidh do mholadh. Chaidh a dhèanamh. Chaidh a pòsadh. Chaidh ar stiùireadh. An deach ur leantail? Cha deach an clò-bhualadh fhathast. | Chuir mi a-staigh airson dreuchd teagaisg ann an àrd-sgoil is chaidh mo thaghadh airson na h-obrach.
I was hit. You were recommended. It was done. She was married. We were directed. Were you followed? They were not printed yet. | I applied for a teaching post in a secondary school and I was chosen for the work. td. 172, 180
Chaidh mo bhreabadh leis an each. Thèid an cur sa phost a-màireach. Rachadh a mhilleadh.
I was kicked by the horse. They will be posted tomorrow. It would be destroyed. td. 477
other examples from modern usage –
Chaidh an sàthadh le rud biorach air choreigin [...]
They were stabbed with something pointed [...] td. 122
’S chaidh a thìodhlacadh ’s chaidh a’ bheairt a reic.
And he was buried and the loom was sold. td. 76
examples with an explicit agent introduced by le with –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh a’ bhùth a cheannach le Iain. | Chaidh a’ chaora a leagail le càr. | An deach Anna a bhreabadh leis an each?
The shop was bought by John. | The sheep was knocked down by a car. | Was Anna kicked by the horse? td. 172–3
Chaidh mo bhreabadh leis an each.
I was kicked by the horse. td. 477

Note that the particle a used in the inverting passives with a non-prononimal direct object is not a possessive determiner meaning his, her, its. Examples like the following with feminine or plural nouns are hypercorrections, influenced by other passive constructions –
Chaidh na fir am marbhadh. The men were killed – Chaidh na fir a mharbhadh.
a’ chailleach a thèid a marbhadh the old woman who will be killed – a’ chailleach a thèid a mharbhadh
See also the original LeaCaG guidance here.
rach can also be used impersonally in a couple of quasi-modal constructions.

module.p:
The impersonal construction rach aig [duine] air [rud a dhèanamh] can be used to express the notion of success – succeed in doing something, manage to do something –
Chaidh aig Raonaid air an uinneag (a) fhosgladh. Rachel managed to open the window.
Cha tèid aice air seinn. She won’t manage to sing.

Some examples –
intransitive –
pedagogical examples –
Tha mi toilichte gun deach agad air tighinn.
I’m glad you managed to come. td. 477
transitive with inversion –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh agam air a’ chraobh a dhìreadh.
I managed to climb the tree. td. 477
transitive with pronoun –
pedagogical examples –
Cha deach aig a nàimhdean air a ghlacadh.
His enemies didn’t succeed in catching him. td. 477
An tèid agad air an toirt a-nuas?
Will you manage to get them down? ??
understood action –
pedagogical examples –
cho tric ’s a thèid agaibh air
as often as you can manage td. 477

Another way of expressing the notion of success is with the impersonal construction rach le [duine] someone succeeds –
Chaidh le Raonaid. Rachel succeeded.
Cha tèid leat. You won’t succeed.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Chun na h-ìre sin chaidh leis. | Chaidh leatha. | Ma thèid leinn ...
To that extent he/it has succeeded. | She succeeded. | If we are successful ... td. 477
Aig toiseach tòiseachaidh b’ e rùn a’ Chomainn foghlam Beurla a thoirt don t-sluagh Ghàidhealach; bha Gàidhlig is Laideann le chèile, uime sin, air an toirmeasg anns na sgoiltean. Ach cha deach leotha.
At the outset the aim of the Society was to provide education in English to the Gaelic population. Gaelic and Latin together were therefore forbidden in the schools. But they did not succeed in that policy. td. 193

A more emphatic variant is rach gu math le [duine] flourish, do well –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh gu math leotha.
They flourished. td. 477
Gun tèid (gu math) leat! | Gur/guma math a thèid leat!
Good luck! td. 177

This construction is used in the following common subjunctive imprecations, all of which mean something like Good luck! –
Gun tèid (gu math) leat!
Gur math a thèid leat!

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Gun tèid (gu math) leat! | Gur/guma math a thèid leat!
Good luck! td. 177

Yet another way of expressing the notion of success is with the impersonal construction rach gu math do [dhuine] –
Chaidh gu math do Raonaid. It went well for Rachel.
An tèid gu math dhut? Will it go well for you?

Some examples –
basic –
pedagogical examples –
An toiseach chaidh dhomh gu math.
At first it went well for me. td. 477
comparatives –
pedagogical examples –
Cha deach dhaibh na b’ fheàrr an sin.
It didn’t go any better for them there. / They didn’t fare any better there. td. 477
with ciamar? how? –
pedagogical examples –
Leigidh sinn fios thugad uaireigin air an ath-sheachdain ciamar a chaidh dhut anns an agallamh.
We’ll let you know sometime next week how you fared in the interview. td. 150 no subject

This construction can also be used non-impersonally, with an explicit subject –
pedagogical examples –
Tha cùisean air a dhol nas miosa dhaibh bhon uairsin.
Matters have become worse for them since then. td. 477 negative, comparative, retrospective

section.p: rach usually takes one or more complements – prepositional phrases or adverbs.
Concrete uses of rach involve a material (generally animate, volitional) subject moving along a trajectory/path in three-dimensional physical space, often with a specific goal/purpose in mind.

A complement of concrete rach can denote the physical trajectory of motion itself, usually with respect to one or more reference objects –
Chaidh Raonaid bho Lunnainn gu Dùn Èideann. Rachel went from London to Edinburgh.
Dheigheamaid a-mach a h-uile feasgar. We would go out every evening.

A path complement can be queried using càite ? (to) where?, whither? –
Càite an deach sibh? Where did you go?

There are a number of prepositions which can be used to introduce concrete path complements of rach –
rach dha ... [do, a] go (in)to something –
proper nouns/names –
pedagogical examples –
Tha Anna a’ dol a-null a Ghlaschu. | Tha mi a’ dol a-null thairis a Pharas. | Chaidh mi a Pheairt a chionn is gun robh mo charaid a’ fuireach ann. | Thèid sinn a Ghlaschu. | Thèid Anna a Ghlaschu a h-uile Dimàirt. | an tidsear a chaidh a mhac a Pheairt | Is ann an-dè a chaidh Iain a Ghlaschu. | Is àbhaist dhomh a bhith a’ dol a dh’Èirinn as t-samhradh. | An àbhaist dha a bhith a’ dol a dh’Uibhist? | Rachainn a Ghlaschu nan tigeadh Anna còmhla rium.
Ann is going over there to Glasgow. | I am going abroad to Paris. | I went to Perth because my friend was living there. | We will go to Glasgow. | Ann goes to Glasgow every Tuesday. | the teacher whose son went to Perth | It is yesterday that John went to Glasgow. | I usually go to Ireland in the summer. | Does he usually go to Uist? | I would go to Glasgow if Ann came with me. td. 31, 66, 105, 118, 120, 121, 144, 170, 176

pedagogical examples –
Rachamaid dhan an taigh-thasgaidh a h-uile mìos. | Nuair a dh’fhàg mi an sgoil, chaidh mi dhan an oilthigh an Dùn Èideann. | A chionn is gum feumadh a h-uile leanabh a-nis dol dhan sgoil, agus leis gur h-e Beurla an aon chainnt ionnsachaidh a bha innte, thug an t-Achd buille mhairbhteach dhan chànan.
We used to go to the museum every month. | When I left school, I went to the university in Edinburgh. | Since every child now had to go to school, and since English was the only language of instruction, the Act gave Gaelic a fatal blow. td. 119 [199], 169 [199], 180, 193
Dh’iarr i orm a dhol don bhuth. Thèid mi air ais don talla. | Chaidh iad don àrd-sgoil anns an ath bhaile. An deach(aidh) iad don eaglais? | Chaidh e a-steach don togalach às an robh an t-seinn a’ tighinn.
She asked me to go to the shop. I’ll go back to the hall. | They went to the high-school in the next town. Did they go to [the] church? | He entered the building from which the singing was coming. td. 476, 477, 49
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. [...] td. 5
rach gu ... go to something/someone –
proper nouns/names –
pedagogical examples –
Bu chòir dhut a dhol gu Baile Àtha Cliath.
You should go to Dublin. td. 154 [199]
Chaidh e gu Glaschu.
He went to (the outskirts of) Glasgow. td. 220
common nouns –
pedagogical examples –
Càite an tèid mi airson nan tiocaidean? Thèid chun an dorais anns a bheil fear an stèisein na sheasamh. | Chaidh an iolaire chun na goibhre is chuir i an dearbh cheist oirrese. [...] Chaidh an iolaire chun a’ bhric.
Where can I go for the tickets? To the door where the station-master is standing. | The eagle went to the goat and out the very same question to her. [...] The eagle went to the salmon. td. 134, 191
rach gu ruige ... –
pedagogical examples –
Agus theich prìosanaich a bha a’ dol gu ruige cùirt.
And prisoners who were going to court escaped. td. 83
rach tro ... go through something/someone

There are many adverbs (and prepositional compounds) which can serve as the complement of rach, denoting a concrete trajectory –
rach a-mach go out(side) (cf. rach a-muigh)
rach a-null go (over there) (cf. rach a-nall)
rach a-steach go in(side), enter
rach air adhart advance, go forwards
rach air ais go back(wards), recede, regress, reverse
rach air bòrd go aboard
rach air thoiseach advance, go forwards
rach dhachaigh go home(wards)
rach sìos go down(wards), charge (in battle) (cf. rach a-nuas, rach shìos)
rach suas go up(wards) (cf. rach a-nìos, rach shuas)
rach seachad go past
rach tarsainn go across/over
rach timcheall go (a)round
rach mun cuairt revolve
rach fon uisge dive, submerge, go underwater
rach ri taobh ... go along(side) ..., rach taobh ... go via ...
rach far an ... go (to the place) where ...

A complement of concrete rach can denote the purpose of the motion, the reason why the volitional subject decided to act in that way. This is usually introduced by the preposition do [a] to governing a verbal noun –
Chaidh Raonaid (dhan bhùth) a dh’fhaighinn isbeanan. Rachel went (to the shop) to get sausages.
Dheigheamaid gam/dham faighinn a h-uile madainn. We would go to get them every morning.

A purpose complement can be queried using carson ? why? –
Carson a chaidh sibh ann? Why did you go?

Some examples –
intransitive –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh Anna a dh’fhuireach còmhla ri Peigi.
Ann went to stay with Peggy. td. 153
Chaidh i a dhannsa còmhla ris.
She went to dance with him. td. 477
transitive –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh iad a cheannach leabhraichean.
They went to buy books. td. 154
Chaidh e a dhùnadh an dorais. Chaidh i a dh’fhosgladh na h-uinneig.
He went to shut the door. She went to open the window. td. 477
transitive with pronoun –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh Iain gan iarraidh. | Chaidh Calum ga coimhead.
John went to get them. | Calum went to watch her. td. 156, 157 [199] ie. dhan iarraidh, dha coimhead
Thuirt e gun robhas a’ dol ga mhort.
He said that he was going to be murdered. td. 477 ie. Thuirt e gun robh duine a’ dol dha mhort.

Some idioms –
rach a/air chèilidh air visit, call in on

When the complement of one of the trajectory prepositions do or gu denotes a social event, the intention is understood as one of attendance –
Chaidh Raonaid gu banais Sheumais. Rachel went to James’ wedding.
Dheighinn gu adhlacadh gach seachdain. I would go to a funeral every week. An alternative interpretation is that these are just path complements meaning to the place where the wedding/funeral happened.

Some examples –
examples with do –
pedagogical examples –
An tèid do bhràthair dhan a’ chèilidh? | An abradh tu gun rachadh Iain dhan an dealbh-chluich?
Will your brother go to the cèilidh? | Would you say that John would go to the drama? td. 119 [199], 169 [199]
Nach tèid iad don chèilidh?
Won’t they go to the ceilidh? td. 476
examples with gu –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh sinn gu cèilidh.
We went to a ceilidh. td. 346
Càite am bi sinn a’ dol a-nochd? Bidh chun a’ chèilidh.
Where will we be going tonight? To the ceilidh. td. 116

Note also examples with air on –
rach air lorg ... go looking for, track, trail
rach air làithean saora go on holiday/vacation

module.p: As seen with the subject above, the complement of concrete rach can only be dropped when it is implied in the response to a question.

In the absence of any other explicit complement or modifier, the prepositional pronoun ann is used as a default trajectory complement –
Chaidh Raonaid ann. Rachel went.

Examples –
pedagogical examples –
Cò a bhios a’ seinn aig a’ chèilidh? Chan eil sìon a dh’fhios agamsa ach tha seinneadairean is pìobairean is fìdhleirean às an àite seo fhèin a’ dol ann. | Tha mise a’ dol ann ma tha Anna a’ tighinn. | Rachainn ann nan tigeadh tusa còmhla rium. | Thathar a’ dol ann a h-uile bliadhna. Dh’fheumte a dhol ann.
Who will be singing at the ceilidh? I’ve no idea, but there are plenty of singers and pipers and fiddlers from this place itself going there. | I am going (there) if Ann is coming. | I would go there if you came along with me. | People are going there every year. People had to go there. td. 116, 138, 168, 173

section.p:
Some quasi-idiomatic usages that seem to involve concrete senses of rach are –
rach fodha* go down, sink
rach air chall get/become lost
rach à(s an t-)sealladh disappear, vanish
rach mu thàmh go to bed
Abstract uses of rach do not involve physical motion along a concrete spatial trajectory.
A complement of abstract rach can denote a new state which the subject transitions into.

module.p:
The new state can be represented by a deadjectival abstract noun, introduced by the preposition an in –
rach am miosad deteriorate, get/become worse –
Tha cogadh is gort a’ dol am miosad.
War and famine are becoming worse. td. 433

A special implementation of this is the pseudo-reflexive rach na* ... become, turn into –
human subjects –
pedagogical examples –
’S dòcha nach rachadh e na dhotair idir.
Perhaps he wouldn’t become a doctor at all. td. 477
... mun deach e na mhinistear
... before he became a minister td. 477
inanimate subjects –
pedagogical examples –
Bha ùir a’ cheuma gu luath a’ dol na h-eabar.
The soil of the path was quickly turning into mud. td. 477 progressive

Some idioms –
rach na* teine catch fire, go on fire –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh an sabhal na theine.
The barn went on fire. td. 478

The new state can be introduced by the preposition à out of –
rach às a* chiall go out of one’s mind –
pedagogical examples –
Theab i a dhol às a ciall.
She almost went out of her mind. td. 177 non-finite verb

The new state can be introduced by the preposition gu to –
rach gu tàmh go to rest, die

section.p:
Other, idiomatic, abstract uses of rach do not seem to involve an obvious change of state –
rach a-mach air quarrel with, fall out with
rach an aghaidh denounce, disagree with, discriminate against, disagree
rach seachad air ignore
rach ri ... gu math make a good job of –
pedagogical examples –
Feuch dè cho math’s a thèid thu ris. | Is math a thèid thu ris, a Mhàiri.
See how good a job you can make of it. | You made a good job of it, Mary. td. 477, ibid
rach ri cuideachd ... take after –
Is ann ri cuideachd athar a chaidh Raghnall.
Ronald favoured his father’s people / looked like his father’s side of the family. td. 478
rach ris an deoch take to drink –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh e ris an deoch.
He took to drink. td. 478
rach an comhairle confer
rach gu sabaid begin to fight –
pedagogical examples –
nuair a chaidh buill a’ chomainn gu sabaid nam measg fhèin
when the members of the society began to fight among themselves td. 478 concrete? inchoative?

Forms of rach can be used with a wide range of adverbial modifiers –
temporal –
pedagogical examples –
Thèid Anna a Ghlaschu a h-uile Dimàirt. | Is ann an-dè a chaidh Iain a Ghlaschu. | Rachamaid dhan an taigh-thasgaidh a h-uile mìos.
Ann goes to Glasgow every Tuesday. | It is yesterday that John went to Glasgow. | We used to go to the museum every month. td. 120, 144, 169 [199]
An rachadh tu air ais a-rithist?
Would you go back again? td. 477
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. Is toigh leis a’ chloinn biadh a ghabhail a muigh ri latha brèagha. Thèid iad dhachaidh feasgar an uair a tha a’ ghrian a’ dol fodha.
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. The children like eating al fresco on a nice day. They will go home in the evening when the sun is going down. td. 6–7
accompanying –
rach còmhla ri ... accompany –
pedagogical examples –
Is ann a dh’fhaodainn fhìn a dhol còmhla riut.
Indeed, I could go with you myself. td. 165
Rachainn còmhla riut nam b’urrainn dhomh. Chaidh i a dhannsa còmhla ris.
I’d go with you if I could. She went to dance with him. td. 477
rach le ... go with, take
pedagogical examples –
An tèid an ad seo leis a’ chòta.
Will this hat go with the coat? td. 478
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” [...] td. 5
concessive/contrastive –
pedagogical examples –
Cha tèid Màiri air lathaichean saora ged a bhios an t-airgead aice.
Mary will not go on holiday even though she will have the money. td. 105
causal/purposive –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh mi a Pheairt a chionn is gun robh mo charaid a’ fuireach ann. | Càite an tèid mi airson nan tiocaidean?
I went to Perth because my friend was living there. | Where can I go for the tickets? td. 105, 134
conditional –
pedagogical examples –
Rachainn a Ghlaschu nan tigeadh Anna còmhla rium.
I would go to Glasgow if Ann came with me. td. 176
Rachainn còmhla riut nam b’urrainn dhomh.
I’d go with you if I could. td. 477

module.p: Relative forms of rach can be used as the complement of the positive relative particle a.
Used with expressions of time to denote last ..., this past ...

Some examples involving days of the week –
pedagogical examples –
Bha mi anns a’ bhaile Disathairne seo (a) chaidh. | Dimàirt seo chaidh
I was in [the] town last Saturday. | last Tuesday td. 478, ibid
dol going is a masculine common noun.
When used as the complement of the progressive particle ag, as in a’ dol (in the process of) going has progressive meaning, and usually occurs as the predicate of the verb bi.
This progressive construction is compatible with most of the senses of non-progressive rach discussed previously.

li.g: a’ dol bho Lunnainn gu Dùn Èideann

section.p:
Some examples involving motion in progress –
pedagogical examples –
Chan eil iad a’ dol a-mach. | Tha Anna a’ dol suas an staidhre. | Tha Anna a’ dol a-null a Ghlaschu. Tha Màiri a’ dol a-mach. | Càit a bheil thu a’ dol? Tha mi a’ dol a-null thairis a Pharas. | Agus theich prìosanaich a bha a’ dol gu ruige cùirt. | Càite am bi sinn a’ dol a-nochd? Bidh chun a’ chèilidh. Cò a bhios a’ seinn aig a’ chèilidh? Chan eil sìon a dh’fhios agamsa ach tha seinneadairean is pìobairean is fìdhleirean às an àite seo fhèin a’ dol ann. | nuair as ann a’ dol dhachaigh a bhios tu | Am faigh mi tiocaid a bheir à seo gu ruige na h-eileanan An-iar mi? Gheibh, agus bidh sin còig notaichean air fhichead, a’ dol taobh an Òbain. | Tha mise a’ dol ann ma tha Anna a’ tighinn. | Is àbhaist dhomh a bhith a’ dol a dh’Èirinn as t-samhradh. An àbhaist dha a bhith a’ dol a dh’Uibhist? Nach àbhaist dhi a bhith a’ dol a-mach feasgar? | Thathar a’ dol ann a h-uile bliadhna.
They are not going out. | Ann is going up the stairs. | Ann is going over there to Glasgow. Mary is going out. | Where are you going? I am going abroad to Paris. | And prisoners who were going to court escaped. | Where will we be going tonight? To the ceilidh. Who will be singing at the ceilidh? I’ve no idea, but there are plenty of singers and pipers and fiddlers from this place itself going there. | when it’s going home that you will be | Can I get a ticket that will take me from here to the Western Isles? Yes, and that will be £25, going via Oban. | I am going (there) if Ann is coming. | I usually go to Ireland in the summer. Does he usually go to Uist? Doesn’t she usually go out in the evening? | People are going there every year. td. 22, 30, 31, 66, 83, 116, 126, 134, 138, 170, 173
Tha mi a’ dol dhachaigh.
I’m going home. td. 476
older pedagogical examples –
Thèid iad dhachaidh feasgar an uair a tha a’ ghrian a’ dol fodha.
They will go home in the evening when the sun is going down. td. 7

However, when used with a purpose complement, bi a’ dol can have a purely prospective (non-motional) interpretation –
Tha Raonaid a’ dol a bhith sgìth. Rachel is going to be tired.
Tha Ailig a’ dol a dhol a dh’Ealaghol. Alec is going to go to Elgol.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Tha Ailean a’ dol a dh’innse dhuinn. | Bha e a’ dol a thighinn. Nach eil thu a’ dol a dh’èisteachd? | Tha Peigi a’ dol a leughadh a’ phàipeir. | Tha mi a’ dol a bhith an Dùn Èideann. Tha Dòmhnall a’ dol a bhith ag obair.
Alan is going to tell us. | He was going to come. Aren’t you going to listen? | Peggy is going to read the paper. | I am going to be in Edinburgh. Donald is going to be working. td. 153, 154 [199], 155, 157
older pedagogical examples –
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr. Chaidh iad sìos taobh an locha is stad iad aig àite bòidheach gorm. Chuir iad an càr a stigh gu taobh an rathaid is thug iad brat a mach as a’ chàr air son suidhe air. Tha bascaid làn de bhiadh aca is tha iad a’ dol a ghabhail an tea air a’ chnocan ghorm. [...]
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. They went down the side of the lake and they stopped at a beautiful green place. They put the car into the side of the road and they took a blanket out of the car for sitting on. They have a basket full of food and they are going to have their tea on the little green hill. [...] td. 6–7

In other cases the interpretation is ambiguous between progressive/prospective and purely prospective –
pedagogical examples –
Tha sinn a’ dol a dh’fhaighinn bainne. Tha sinn a’ dol ga choimhead. Tha Anna a’ dol gan dùsgadh.
We are going to get milk. We are going to watch him/it. Ann is going to waken them. td. 156–7 [199]

The rach aig ... air ... manage to ... construction can be used in the progressive –
Bha a’ dol aig Raonaid air an uinneag (a) fhosgladh. Rachel was managing to open the window.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Chan eil dol aige air na puingean seo a dhearbhadh.
He doesn’t succeed in proving these points. td. 477

Some figurative and difficult to categorise examples –
pedagogical examples –
Dè an rathad tha dol do Phortrìgh (Phort Ruighe)?
Which road leads to Portree? td. 478 spatial extent
Chan eil dol às bhuaipe [bhon a’ cheist].
There is no getting away from it. td. 478
Cha do dh’fhairich sinn an oidhche a’ dol seachad.
We didn’t feel the night passing. td. 165 Chaidh an oidhche seachad.

Some examples with adverbial modifiers –
pedagogical examples –
Is àbhaist dhomh a bhith a’ dol a dh’Èirinn as t-samhradh. Nach àbhaist dhi a bhith a’ dol a-mach feasgar? | Thathar a’ dol ann a h-uile bliadhna. | Tha mise a’ dol ann ma tha Anna a’ tighinn.
I usually go to Ireland in the summer. | Doesn’t she usually go out in the evening? | People are going there every year. | I am going if Anna is coming. td. 170, 173, 138

cùm a’ dol keep going –
Bha m’ athair ri iasgach. Bha e air a chumail a’ dol.
My father was at the fishing. He was kept going/busy. td. 180 Is this retrospective or passive retrospective?

Note also the following ‘complement-less’ use of abstract bi a’ dol –
Dè [a] tha a’ dol? What’s going on? What’s up?

Examples –
pedagogical examples –
Dè (a) tha a’ dol?
What is going (on)? td. 22 no complement
A bheil iad a’ tuigsinn dè tha (a’) dol?
Do they realise what’s going on? td. 478

module.p: The form used in non-finite clauses is usually a dhol, rather than just dol.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Bu chòir dhut a dhol gu Baile Àtha Cliath. | Is ann a dh’fhaodainn fhìn a dhol còmhla riut. | Cha toireadh màthair Dhòmhnaill cead dha a dhol a-mach. | Dh’fheumte a dhol ann.
You should go to Dublin. | Indeed, I could go with you myself. | Donald’s mother would not give him permission to go out. | People had to go there. td. 154 [199], 165, 169 [199], 173
Dh’iarr i orm a dhol don bhùth.
She asked me to go to the shop. td. 476
air a dhol have gone is a retrospective compound, with the deverbal noun appearing as the complement of the retrospective preposition air. It usually occurs as the predicate of the verb bi.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Tha/bha/bidh/bhiodh iad air a dhol a-mach.
They (will/would) have/had gone out. td. 158–9
